channel.title: Just installed Xubuntu
channel.description:
I've been using Windows XP for 99999999999. As a lot of people know, as the age of an XP installation approaches infinite, performance approaches zero. So after getting to the stage that I was about to start smacking my computer to make it go faster (Jethro Gibbs from NCIS reference!), I decided to give linux another try. In the past, I've used SabayonLinux and Kubuntu, and potentially something else (the name eludes me). All of them used the KDE desktop environment, but it never grew on me -- I absolutely loathed it.
So this time I decided to give Xubuntu a shot, because it uses Xfce (which I've heard great things about from numerous people). So far I love it. I don't know whether it has something KDE doesn't, or the other way around. In fact, I probably like it because it lacks the 9999 customisable features that the KDE environment has. Mind you, this is coming from someone who has had the default windows xp desktop since the last time he did a reinstall. I hate feeling like I have to fiddle with things (and, in my opinion, KDE makes its users fiddle with things).
So yeah, hopefully all goes well. There's a bit of software I have to get, but that shouldn't take long given that I don't do much on the computer anyway (uni work, youtube, irc, general browsing, programming here and there).

item.title: Just installed Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @Koolvin Koolvin
item.description:
@Koolvin wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:12, topic:337423”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=433822.msg3185890#msg3185890 date=1271728879]
If you do get Windows 7 and your computer is somewhat old, I highly suggest installing an x86 windows architecture seeing as some old 64-bit drivers are very, very buggy in comparison to the 32-bit ones.

I speak from personal experience.

Anyways, seeing as how I recently reinstalled 32-bit since I couldn’t stand the random freezes I’d have with 64-bit along with the general slowness of everything, I had to boot into my Xubuntu partition since my XP partition is also very slow and sometimes causes a BSOD (that install is from like 3 years ago, I can’t be fucked to reinstall) in order to back up important things from my win7 partition since it got to the stage where booting was unbearable and it would freeze at intervals of around 2 minutes, so I was thinking of switching back to linux for a while. After I reinstalled 32-bit, however, I just couldn’t be bothered.
[/quote]
cough cool story bro.[/quote]my exact thoughts.

Read full topic

item.title: Just installed Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Ive got windows 7 on an old pentium 4 and it breathes new life into it, I wouldn’t notice the difference between this computer and a new computer except for the fact that I can’t doing gaming because the video card sucks and no pci-e x16 slot, only pci.

Read full topic

item.title: Just installed Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

If you do get Windows 7 and your computer is somewhat old, I highly suggest installing an x86 windows architecture seeing as some old 64-bit drivers are very, very buggy in comparison to the 32-bit ones.

I speak from personal experience.

Anyways, seeing as how I recently reinstalled 32-bit since I couldn’t stand the random freezes I’d have with 64-bit along with the general slowness of everything, I had to boot into my Xubuntu partition since my XP partition is also very slow and sometimes causes a BSOD (that install is from like 3 years ago, I can’t be fucked to reinstall) in order to back up important things from my win7 partition since it got to the stage where booting was unbearable and it would freeze at intervals of around 2 minutes, so I was thinking of switching back to linux for a while. After I reinstalled 32-bit, however, I just couldn’t be bothered.

But yeah, definitely a good choice.

Read full topic

item.title: Just installed Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Xfce is my second favorite DE, KDE 3.5 being my favorite, but choice is what linux is all about and if we all wanted to look at the same old thing we would probably just stick with windows. Anyway that means about all the admin run linux, so that’s good.

Read full topic

item.title: Just installed Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Although it doesn’t compare to being as fast as Arch

If you don’t quite fancy Arch’s customisation, you could also try Fedora, which is also now 686 targeted and so pretty speedy, though there’s a lot more cruft running than in an Arch install ofc.

Read full topic

item.title: Just installed Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Smart move. I will agree with c|p about Windows 7 though, it’s pretty damn fast.

Read full topic

item.title: Just installed Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

If you reach the conclusion that you do not like Xubuntu, or Linux in general, give Windows 7 a try.
Alternatively, you might want to look into becoming a pseudo-poweruser and try Arch.

If you have a decent machine, Windows 7 is more or less just as speedy as a fresh XP install. Honestly it is way better, from my experience.

Read full topic

item.title: Just installed Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:5, topic:337423”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=433822.msg3185425#msg3185425 date=1271688762]
I’ve been using Windows XP for 99999999999. As a lot of people know, as the age of an XP installation approaches infinite, performance approaches zero.
[/quote]
in my case its very weird, ive been running xp for > 3 years and its still almost as fast as a fresh install. it wasnt like this before though, i was about to reinstall because everything was slow as balls, then by chance i uninstalled msvs2005 and all the shit that was slow got fast again. the only problem atm is slow boot[/quote]
Haha. Yeah, slow boot times are a real pain in the arse. Mine was unbearable.

Read full topic

item.title: Just installed Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

Lothy:

I’ve been using Windows XP for 99999999999. As a lot of people know, as the age of an XP installation approaches infinite, performance approaches zero.

in my case its very weird, ive been running xp for > 3 years and its still almost as fast as a fresh install. it wasnt like this before though, i was about to reinstall because everything was slow as balls, then by chance i uninstalled msvs2005 and all the shit that was slow got fast again. the only problem atm is slow boot

Read full topic

item.title: Just installed Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @thiefmn6092 thiefmn6092
item.description:
@thiefmn6092 wrote:

Lothy:

I never actually tried GNOME. I just know that every time I’ve used a KDE-based distro, I’ve ended up hating myself and reverting to windows XP.

i consider gnome to be in the middle of xfce and kde, in that it still has decent looks and does not require much configuration (if any, depending on how basic you really consider yourself). like, i just changed a few things using gconf and some font settings, all trivial of course. other than those, i did not touch it at all. on the ubuntu topic, you really should just spend a day of free time trying out different distributions. you might find you like others more than ubuntu. although ubuntu could be considered the mainstream linux distribution, distros like fedora or arch linux (if you don’t like configging, do NOT use this since you have to conf the window system using guides pretty much) are cool as well. its like woman, some like them fat or skinny. just like how moparisthebest likes them around 250 pounds and i like them petite and small. (i think it would be safe to say in this instance, moparisthebest likes ubuntu since it resembles the 250 pound woman).

Read full topic

item.title: Just installed Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I never actually tried GNOME. I just know that every time I’ve used a KDE-based distro, I’ve ended up hating myself and reverting to windows XP.

Read full topic

item.title: Just installed Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @thiefmn6092 thiefmn6092
item.description:
@thiefmn6092 wrote:

yeah, xfce is pretty nice. it does not use a lot of resources and still has that crisp basic ui look to it. i know what you mean with KDE, it is horrible imo. aside from the configuration required, it crashes all of the time on my laptop (yes, i am a cheap bastard and use a like 7 year old laptop :(), so i could never stand it. my two choices are always xfce or GNOME, personally. or… just the command line with nano and some app that lets me browse the web in text if i am feeling really 1980’s, haha

Read full topic
